channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine News: Civilians Are Urged to Flee Russian-Occupied Areas in South
item.description: In eastern Ukraine, U.S. officials say, Moscow is likely to end up with more territory, but neither side will gain full control of the region. China and India are snapping up Russian crude, bolstering Moscow’s economy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: China’s Surveillance State Is Growing. These Documents Reveal How.
item.description: A New York Times analysis of over 100,000 government bidding documents found that China’s ambition to collect digital and biological data from its citizens is more expansive and invasive than previously known.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Paul Mozur, Isabelle Qian and Alexander Cardia

item.title: Israel’s Government Collapses, Setting Up 5th Election in 3 Years
item.description: The governing coalition decided to dissolve Parliament, plunging the country back into paralysis and throwing a political lifeline to Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, left, and Foreign Minister Yair Lapid after making their joint statement on Monday.

item.title: Gustavo Petro Promised to Transform Colombia as President. Can He Do It?
item.description: During his campaign, Gustavo Petro proposed major reforms if he was elected. After winning Sunday’s presidential election, he’ll now have to prove he can carry out those changes.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gustavo Petro, center, and Francia Márquez, first from right, celebrating after winning the presidential election on Sunday in Bogotá.

item.title: Why Does Israel Have So Many Elections?
item.description: Israelis are heading back to the polls for the fifth time in under four years.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, left, speaks during a joint statement with Foreign Minister Yair Lapid, at the Knesset, Israel's parliament, in Jerusalem, Monday.

item.title: China’s Expanding Surveillance State: Takeaways From a NYT Investigation
item.description: Times reporters spent over a year combing through government bidding documents that reveal the country’s technological road map to ensure the longevity of its authoritarian rule.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Qian, Muyi Xiao, Paul Mozur and Alexander Cardia
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: In Ukraine, One Woman’s Shopping Trip Over the Last Bridge in Lysychansk
item.description: Bridges are critical in the battle for Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, separated by a river. Shelling has mostly destroyed them, but that didn’t stop one woman from walking across to buy some basics.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Libyans Try to Move On From Conflict With Comedy and Burgers
item.description: After more than a decade of chaos and war, fed-up Libyans are clamoring for peace — and making clear they’ve had enough violence: “We want to taste life, not death.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: S​outh Korea Launches Satellite With Its Own Rocket for the First Time
item.description: The launch brings the country closer to its ambition of becoming a player in the space industry, no longer reliant on technology from other countries.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Nuri, South Korea’s first domestically produced space rocket, lifting off from a launchpad at the Naro Space Center in Goheung, South Korea, on Tuesday.

item.title: Australian Judge Delays Brittany Higgins Rape Trial
item.description: A journalist’s remarks ran afoul of tight limits on speech connected to criminal prosecutions, putting pause on a high-profile case about to start.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Brittany Higgins in Canberra, Australia, in February. Her allegation of being sexually assaulted by a colleague while working in Parliament drew attention to what many women described as a toxic workplace where sexual harassment was pervasive.

item.title: U.K. Hobbled By Largest Rail Strike in Three Decades
item.description: Travel was disrupted for tens of millions of people during the country’s biggest walkout in decades as union leaders warned of a summer of labor unrest.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Eshe Nelson
item.category: National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT)
item.media:description: Waterloo Station in London on Tuesday. After last-ditch talks between the main union and the rail operator collapsed, hundreds of trains ground to a halt for the first of three planned days of strikes.

item.title: Jumbo, Hong Kong’s Floating Restaurant, Sinks After Capsizing
item.description: Jumbo Floating Restaurant, which closed in 2020, capsized in the South China Sea after being towed from the city. The sinking triggered nostalgia for a happier period of Hong Kong history.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Jumbo Floating Restaurant being towed out out of Aberdeen Harbor in Hong Kong last week.

item.title: The Killing of Shireen Abu Akleh: Tracing a Bullet to an Israeli Convoy
item.description: A New York Times investigation found that the bullet that killed a Palestinian-American journalist was fired from the approximate position of an Israeli military vehicle.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Patrick Kingsley, Christiaan Triebert, Hiba Yazbek and Phil Robibero

item.title: 132 Civilians Killed by Rebel Attacks in Central Mali, Government Says
item.description: Several villages near the town of Bankass were attacked over the weekend by jihadists, officials said.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: The head of Mali’s ruling junta, Col. Assimi Goita, declared three days of mourning.

item.title: How Russia Is Making More in Oil Sales Now Than Before the War
item.description: With China and India buying the Russian oil shunned by the West in an effort to force an end to the Ukraine invasion, Moscow is earning more now than it did before the war.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim, Clifford Krauss and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Lukoil refinery in Volgograd, Russia.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Asia Buys Up Russia’s Oil
item.description: Also, a Times investigation into China’s expanding surveillance capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: The Yang Mei Hu oil products tanker moored at a crude oil terminal in Nakhodka, Russia, this month.

item.title: Israeli Government Collapse Gives Netanyahu Another Chance at Power
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, lost power last year. But his base hasn’t abandoned him, and he could return to office after a snap election this fall.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, speaking at a protest in April, has vowed to return to power.

item.title: Biden Bans Most Antipersonnel Land Mine Use, Reversing Trump-Era Policy
item.description: The move effectively returns to a 2014 policy that forbade the use of the weapons except in defense of South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and John Ismay
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers searched for land mines in the Demilitarized Zone in 2018. The Biden administration is maintaining an exception for land mine use along the heavily militarized border between North and South Korea.

item.title: Many parents in the U.S. have tough questions about the vaccines for young children.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Timothy Ivy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunny Baker, 35, of Oxford, Miss. said she is eager to get the vaccine for her daughter, Alma Pearl Baker, 2. “We would love to be first in line.” she said.

item.title: Documenta Takes Down Art After Antisemitism Accusations
item.description: Organizers of the international art exhibition in Germany said they would remove a work after diplomats and lawmakers said it contained antisemitic images.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Uwe Zucchi/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: “People’s Justice,” a nearly 60-foot-long painted banner by the Indonesian collective Taring Padi, was covered over on Monday. Documenta’s organizers said on Tuesday they would begin removing the work.

item.title: Merrick Garland Visits Ukraine to Discuss Russian War Crimes
item.description: In an unannounced trip, the U.S. attorney general met with prosecutors and said perpetrators of atrocities have “no place to hide.”
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Attorney General Merrick Garland met on Tuesday with Ukraine’s prosecutor general, Iryna Venediktova.

item.title: Asia is buying discounted Russian oil, making up for Europe’s cutbacks.
item.description: The shift has allowed Moscow to maintain its production levels and defy analysts’ expectations that its output would plunge.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: The Yang Mei Hu oil products tanker moored at a crude oil terminal in Nakhodka, Russia, this month.

item.title: The Painful Path to Fight Inflation
item.description: The government’s plan to fight inflation could cost jobs and restrict wage growth.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Shopping for food in Brooklyn last week.

item.title: Chinese Omicron Study Renews Debate Over ‘Zero Covid’ Policy
item.description: The study found that the variant carried a relatively low risk of severe illness.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in Beijing last week.

item.title: Finding Traces of Harriet Tubman on Maryland’s Eastern Shore
item.description: A historian marks the 200th birthday of a fearless conductor of the Underground Railroad with a visit to her birthplace, only to learn how climate change is washing away memories of “the ultimate outdoors woman.”
item.dc:creator: Martha S. Jones
item.media:description: No place better remembers the abolitionist Harriet Tubman than Maryland’s Eastern Shore, where she was born enslaved 200 years ago. Much of her story is told through its land.

item.title: 1972: A 36-Day Hunger Strike Ends in Northern Ireland
item.description: Irish Republican Army members imprisoned in a Belfast jail called an end to a protest that lasted more than a month.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A small town has become a turning point in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at the scene of at least one missile strike hit what appeared to be a military depot in the eastern Ukrainian town of Druzhkivka Monday night.

item.title: U.S. Officials Predict Path of War in Ukraine
item.description: As Russia makes slow but steady progress, the arrival of new weapons systems will help Ukraine hang on to territory, U.S. officials and analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers atop an armored fighting vehicle in an area near Kramatorsk, in the Donbas region, early this month.

item.title: Russian Journalist’s Nobel Medal Sells for $103.5 Million
item.description: Dmitri A. Muratov, the editor of the independent newspaper Novaya Gazeta, will donate proceeds to UNICEF to help Ukrainian child refugees.
item.dc:creator: Kalia Richardson
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dmitri A. Muratov won the Nobel Peace Prize last October.

item.title: Russia’s Blockade of Ukraine Is ‘War Crime,’ Top E.U. Official Says
item.description: The remarks by the official, Josep Borrell Fontelles, were among the strongest language from a Western leader in describing the Kremlin’s tactics to subjugate Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Andrew Higgins, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at the scene of a missile strike on what appeared to be a military depot in the eastern town of Druzhkivka on Monday night.

item.title: ‘We Are Not Safe’: Ethiopians Flee Massacre That Killed Hundreds
item.description: The massacre in Oromia, the nation’s largest region, came as the country grappled with a grueling civil war and the worst drought in decades.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Security forces in the town of Jimma, in the Oromia region of Ethiopia last year.

item.title: Kremlin Calls Captured Americans ‘Soldiers of Fortune’
item.description: Moscow says the Americans who fought for Ukraine are not regular soldiers who would be covered by the Geneva Conventions, calling their conduct criminal.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Israel’s Governing Coalition Collapses
item.description: Also, forced labor is found in China’s battery supply and Colombia elects a new president.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett spoke at a cabinet meeting at the Prime minister's office in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: A Russian official says Ukraine hit drilling rigs in the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexei Druzhinin/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Sergey Aksyonov, the leader of Crimea, said on Monday that the strikes had hit natural gas rigs but that gas supplies were not affected.

item.title: Ruinous Flooding in India and Bangladesh Kills at Least 116
item.description: In regions of the two countries still reeling from flooding in May, monsoon rains brought more misery, with hundreds of thousands of people evacuated and communications cut.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: Indian army personnel rescuing people from flood waters in the northeastern Indian state of Assam, on Monday.

item.title: In pictures: The flaming ruin left by a strike, one of thousands near the eastern front.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Hicks

item.title: The Mystery of Fleet Street: An Article on Boris Johnson Vanishes
item.description: What happened to a story published in The Times of London that was critical of Prime Minister Boris Johnson? The disappearance has London’s media world guessing.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his wife, Carrie, in London this month.

item.title: EU Calls Russia’s Blockade of Ukranian Grain a War Crime
item.description: The war is contributing to global food shortages and rising prices, and the United Nations warns of possible famine. Ukraine is usually a major grain exporter.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wheat stored at a farm on the outskirts of Lviv, Ukraine, in May.

item.title: 5 British Men Released by Taliban as U.K. Expresses Regret
item.description: Britain apologized for “any breach of Afghan culture, customs or laws” by the detainees and said their travel to Afghanistan was “a mistake.”
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zabihullah Mujahid, a spokesman for the Taliban, at a news conference in Kabul last year.

item.title: Israel Confirms Regional Military Project, Showing Its Growing Role
item.description: The Israeli defense minister, Benny Gantz, said Israel was working with other countries in the Middle East to combat Iranian military threats.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Benny Gantz, Israel’s defense minister, during a session of the Knesset this month.

item.title: Russia steps up bombardments of Kharkiv, where Ukraine had pushed back its forces.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:description: A fire in Kharkiv’s Nemyshlianski district after shelling in the Ukrainian city on Monday.

item.title: Grenfell Tower Still Stands. So Do Questions About What to Do With It.
item.description: Five years ago a fast-moving blaze in the London high-rise left 72 people dead and the building a shell. Some want to see it torn down, but others feel it should remain.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Five years after the fire, the shell of Grenfell Tower still stands in West London. The government has not yet decided what to do with the building.

item.title: Hear the stories of Ukrainians who were forcibly resettled to Russia and escaped.
item.dc:creator: Simon Ostrovsky, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Alessandro Pavone

item.title: Russia becomes China’s biggest crude-oil supplier as Europe cuts imports.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Immigration officers inspecting a crude-oil tanker at the Chinese port of Qingdao in May.

item.title: A Fragmented Parliament Brings Macron Back Down to Earth
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron largely sidelined Parliament during his first term. But now he has lost his absolute majority in the lower house, forcing him to seek compromise with a reinvigorated opposition.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi, Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron voting in Le Touquet, northern France, on Sunday. His centrist coalition secured 245 seats in the 577-seat National Assembly.

item.title: A Wildfire Year
item.description: Three million acres have already burned in the West.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu and Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke plumes rising from the Calf Canyon/Hermits Peak fire in Las Vegas, N.M., last month.

item.title: A Herd in Exile: Riding Horses on Mozambique’s Bazaruto Archipelago
item.description: A photographer spent a few weeks helping run a horseback riding program on the white-sand beaches of Benguerra Island. Here’s what she saw.
item.dc:creator: Claire Thomas
item.media:description: A sunset swim on Benguerra Island, the second largest island in the Bazaruto Archipelago.

item.title: Red Flags for Forced Labor Found in China’s Car Battery Supply Chain
item.description: Ties to potentially coercive labor practices could prove a problem for an industry that is heavily dependent on China, once a new law barring Xinjiang products goes into effect.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The electric battery assembly area of an auto parts factory in Hangzhou, China. Many goods produced using forced labor appear to flow into China’s vast ecosystem of factories.

item.title: A new brand of activist takes aim at the Ukraine war and the climate crisis, together.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in May at Schuman Square in Brussels pushing for a total ban on Russian energy. The woman shouting into a megaphone is Dominika Lasota, who has emerged as a protest leader.

item.title: Surviving Russia’s ‘Filtration Camps’
item.description: Thousands of refugees from Ukraine have been sent to so-called filtration camps, where they have been interrogated and then forced to resettle to Russia. Some Ukrainians escaped to Estonia. They told us their stories.
item.dc:creator: Simon Ostrovsky, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Alessandro Pavone
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: New Brand of Activist Takes Aim at Ukraine War and Climate Crisis, Together
item.description: Led by young women from Eastern Europe, they are cornering Europe’s leaders and pressing them for a total energy embargo on Russia — to end the fighting and to save the planet.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in May at Schuman Square in Brussels pushing for a total ban on Russian energy. The woman shouting into a megaphone is Dominika Lasota, who has emerged as a protest leader.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s brutal campaign to capture Sievierodonetsk.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Ukrainian battle tanks heading in the direction of Toshkivka Sunday afternoon.

item.title: Gustavo Petro Wins the Election, Becoming Colombia’s First Leftist Leader
item.description: The former rebel and longtime senator’s victory sets the third largest nation in Latin America on a sharply new path.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gustavo Petro and Francia Márquez celebrating after winning the presidential election on Sunday in Bogotá, Colombia.

item.title: Ukraine Bans Some Russian Music and Books
item.description: The Ukrainian Parliament voted to ban some Russian media and sent two bills to President Zelensky to sign.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Elizaveta Andreevna Gyrdymova, a Russian singer-songwriter, performing during an anti-war concert in Warsaw in April.

item.title: Macron Loses Absolute Majority in Parliament as Opposition Surges
item.description: For the first time in 20 years, a newly-elected French president failed to win an absolute majority in Parliament, forcing President Macron to deal with a defiant left and a resurgent far-right.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron voting on Sunday in Le Touquet, France.

item.title: Before He Ran for President, Gustavo Petro Was a Guerrilla Fighter
item.description: Petro belonged to M-19, born in 1970 as a response to alleged fraud in that year’s presidential elections. It was far smaller than the country’s main guerrilla force, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.
item.dc:creator: Megan Janetsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gustavo Petro last month in Santa Marta, Colombia.

item.title: Paul Haggis Arrested on Sexual Assault Charges in Italy
item.description: Haggis, who wrote and directed the Oscar-winning crime drama “Crash,” was accused of assaulting a woman in Ostuni over the course of two days.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: Paul Haggis, who was arrested on charges of aggravated sexual violence and aggravated personal injuries in Southern Italy. “He is totally innocent,” his lawyer Priya Chaudhry said.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Makes Slow Gains in the Donbas Region
item.description: Also, France’s president lost a majority in Parliament and Colombians voted for their next leader.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Volunteers urged residents of Lysychansk, Ukraine, to evacuate on Sunday.

item.title: Russian Forces Tighten Noose Around Important Cities in Ukraine’s East
item.description: The area around Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk is about three-quarters encircled by Russians, leaving only a slender gap there for Ukrainian troops to maneuver.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Vivian Yee, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops headed Sunday toward Toshkivka, Ukraine, a small town southeast of the metropolitan area of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk. It was not clear late Sunday which side controlled Toshkivka.

item.title: Children of Ukraine’s Fallen Soldiers Spend Father’s Day in New Grief
item.description: As the war’s death toll continues to climb, families mourn the losses of fathers-turned-soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oksana Stepanenko and her daughter Mariia at their home in Rudne, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Over 200 Feared Dead in Ethiopia Massacre
item.description: The killings were the latest to roil the Horn of Africa nation, which is reeling from a civil war that began almost two years ago.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia addressing the Parliament in Addis Ababa in June. Last week, Mr. Abiy announced the establishment of a committee to negotiate peace with the Tigrayans.
